title: How to Do a Surface Dive

steps.title: Begin by floating or swimming face-down, with your arms extended out in front of you.
steps.content: Begin by floating or swimming face-down, with your arms extended out in front of you. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Sweep your arms back, bend your knees, tuck your legs toward your chest & bend your waist forward, so your head is pointing toward the bottom.
steps.content: Sweep your arms back, bend your knees, tuck your legs toward your chest & bend your waist forward, so your head is pointing toward the bottom. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Straighten your legs and your body until you're upside-down & perpendicular to the surface, with your legs sticking up out of the water.
steps.content: Straighten your legs and your body until you're upside-down & perpendicular to the surface, with your legs sticking up out of the water. Extend your arms towards the bottom & point your toes. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Once in this upside-down position, the weight of your legs in the air above will push you underwater.
steps.content: Once in this upside-down position, the weight of your legs in the air above will push you underwater.

steps.title: Tread water in the deep end of the pool.
steps.content: Tread water in the deep end of the pool. [4] X Research source

steps.title: While treading water, kick your legs faster and take a breath of air.
steps.content: While treading water, kick your legs faster and take a breath of air. This will raise you up a little and provide momentum.

steps.title: Stop kicking and keep your body straight.
steps.content: Stop kicking and keep your body straight.

steps.title: Push the water up with your arms, then slide them back down.
steps.content: Push the water up with your arms, then slide them back down. Repeat until you reach the bottom or run out of breath. [5] X Research source . This is commonly called a "feet-first surface dive".
